awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Hemp-derived advanced manufacturing of fabrics
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the potential development of electrified fabric and protective clothing. The possible applications may include uniforms for workers at hospitals, nursing homes, schools, hotels, public transportation, and crowded public areas to reduce the potential transmission of pathogens. For example, hemp incorporated nanofibrous polyurethane membrane, prepared by electrospinning, could be employed as wound dressings.  The potential antibacterial properties of hemp, its porous physical structure, air permeability, and absorbency capabilities may add advantageous features to wound dressing. The cellulose fiber from hemp is used to make many products, including jeans, shirts, dresses, hats, bags, ropes and canvas, skincare products, building materials, and paper. 

This I-Corps project is based on the potential development of an anti-microbial fabric that can be woven into day-to-day wearable clothing, personal protective equipment, or wound care dressings. The proposed technology may contain a current-carrying mesh coated with tetrafluoroethylene and further coated with active photocatalytic material to create hydroxyl radicals from ambient air. Microorganisms, smoke particles, industrial pollutants, odor molecules, and allergens could be structurally dissociated into protein fragments and natural molecules after exposure to the electric field. The decontamination may be amplified by either a negative or positive electrostatic charge to the suspended particles as they encounter the technology, which may assist in migrating the particles to the activated, dismantling mesh containing an internal, oppositely charged attraction screen.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public details the outcomes and findings of our National Science Foundation (NSF)-funded project on the development of innovative fabric technologies using hemp-derived cellulose fibers. These outcomes address both the intellectual merit and broader impacts of our work.

Intellectual Merit

Our project aimed to leverage the unique properties of hemp to develop advanced fabric technologies with potential applications in various industries, including healthcare and public safety. The major achievements of this project include:

  1. Development of Electrified and Anti-microbial Fabric: We successfully developed fabric technologies that integrate electrified elements and anti-microbial properties. These fabrics can potentially reduce the transmission of pathogens in public settings such as hospitals and public transportation.

  2. Innovative Material Development: We utilized hemp-derived cellulose fibers to create fabrics that combine traditional textile manufacturing with cutting-edge technologies like electrospinning and nanotechnology.

  3. Versatility in Application: The developed technologies show promise for use in a wide range of products beyond clothing, including building materials and furniture, showcasing the versatility of hemp as a sustainable material.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of our project are substantial, affecting various sectors and contributing to societal benefits:

  1. Environmental and Health Benefits: The technologies developed contribute to environmental sustainability and public health through the creation of fabrics that can dismantle and neutralize harmful microorganisms and pollutants.

  2. Training and Professional Development: The project provided significant training and professional development opportunities, particularly in entrepreneurial skills and customer discovery processes. A key outcome has been the preparation of the next generation of scientists and engineers with a blend of technical knowledge and business acumen.

  3. Interdisciplinary Research Promotion: By merging concepts from different scientific realms, the project set a precedent for future research projects that require a collaborative approach across multiple scientific disciplines.

Conclusion

The NSF I-Corps project on hemp-derived advanced manufacturing of fabrics has demonstrated significant intellectual merit and broader impacts. Our innovative approaches not only advanced the base of knowledge in material science and textile engineering but also set new standards for environmental sustainability and public health safety. The project outcomes are expected to have lasting effects on industry practices, academic research, and societal well-being.


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Satyanarayan Dev
